Authors:
Delio Endres Júnior, Genivaldo Alves-Silva, Márcio Hisayuki
Sasamori, Rosa Mara Borges-Silveira, Annette Droste
Title:
Tulasnella amonilioides as an efficient mycorrhizal fungus
for symbiotic propagation of the threatened epiphyte Cattleya intermedia
(Orchidaceae)
Keywords:
Cantharellales, Epulorhiza sp., Orchid conservation,
Phylogenetic analysis, Symbiosis
Abstract:
This study aimed to isolate and identify mycorrhizal fungi
capable of promoting the germination of Cattleya intermedia, as well as
to evaluate the development of individuals by symbiotic propagation.
This is the first report of a symbiotic relationship for this species.
We compared seed germination percentage and the growth index of
91-day-old plants propagated symbiotically in OMA medium with plants
that were non-symbiotically propagated in MS medium. Morphometric
variables of the individuals after one year in both media were also
compared. Fungi isolates were identified by phylogenetic analysis and
eight of the nine isolates that were efficient in C. intermedia
propagation were identified as Tulasnella amonilioides. Cattleya
intermedia germinated (rupture of testa by embryo enlargement) without
fungi inoculation, but most of the cultures with T. amonilioides
inoculation experienced improved seed germination and plant development,
with averages being significantly higher than the OMA control and equal
to MS medium. Plants propagated by symbiotic culture with T.
amoliniloides produced more leaves and longer roots, while shoot height
and number of roots were lower than for plants propagated in MS medium
with the addition of activated charcoal. Fresh mass of plants propagated
by symbiotic and asymbiotic techniques were equal, except when plants
were grown in MS without activated charcoal. We conclude that T.
amonilioides has potential for C. intermedia propagation and use for
future reintroduction purposes and restoration projects.
